Chapter 3 Missing values First, we load the data and show the first couple lines here. ## X name food_review ambience_review value_review service_review price_range review_count average_review restaurant_main_type ## 1 1 Cafe Du Soleil 4.2 4.4 4.1 4.2 $30 and under 905 Reviews 4.3 French ## 2 2 Elea 4.7 4.5 4.2 4.5 $50 and over 573 Reviews 4.7 Greek ## 3 3 Nice Matin 4.4 4.3 4.2 4.5 $31 to $50 2840 Reviews 4.5 French ## 4 4 Serafina 105 4.3 4.2 4.1 4.4 $30 and under 142 Reviews 4.4 Italian ## 5 5 Bodrum Turkish Mediterranean 4.6 4.3 4.5 4.5 $30 and under 988 Reviews 4.6 Turkish ## 6 6 French Roast Uptown 4.4 4.4 4.2 4.4 $31 to $50 223 Reviews 4.4 French American Then, we check the number of NA’s in each column. ## X name food_review ambience_review value_review service_review price_range ## 0 0 10 10 10 10 0 ## review_count average_review restaurant_main_type ## 0 0 0 There are 10 NA’s in each review columns. To find out where they are, we plot the missing patterns in data by rows with mi package. From the plot above, we can see that all 10 missing values are in the same rows, so we decided to remove these rows by using na.omit() function.
